reviews.review_msg: This course is challenging, so prior knowledge of securities helps. The professor is good, but attending class is essential. There's no Canvas, so staying organized is important. Grading is based on three assignments (10% each), a group project (30%), and a final (30%). It's manageable if you stay on top of things.

GP is the best guy in the entire faculty. Course is very structured and participation in lectures is encouraged as he discusses everything that is to be expected in the final and the assignments. You can submit all the assignments along with the take-home final near the end of the semester, except for the in-class presentations which are chill.

Great to build your market senses. Yes, Geoffrey is definitely the first prof that I know who just ran away after the lecture (so be sure you read the book). There is definitely a threshold to understand what he really does in the class, but he will explain the topic through the class. If you want to learn how to invest, I highly recommend it.
Plenty of useful insights into markets.  Really liked the approach that relied on thinking rather than memorizing.  Groups project was really helpful to get to know companies.

Requires some basic understanding of stocks to do well.  Avoid this course if you are looking for a lower level step-by-step academic treatment of common stocks.  Course is aimed at real world understanding of what is happening in the markets.

Not a hard prof but the content is extremely outdated (methods 20-30 years old) and more focused on satisfying his investment interests. Totally egotistical. If you actually care about finance and what you're learning for recruitment purposes, definitely avoid. If you're looking for a decent grade for satisfying the prof's ego, this is your man.

For 417, he teaches a way of thinking instead of a step-by-step guide. So, there is some ambiguity that you need intelligence to manage. If you can't, it will feel like you aren't learning anything. But for assignments he tells you exactly what he is looking for. All you gotta do is do it. I would recommend taking a class with him!
Not sure about the previous reviewer that learned nothing, class contains essential real world applications. Great course!
I did not learn anything.

Reading some of the comments here, I am just baffled with students that don't get how precious Geoffrey is. He's the closest thing we have to Ben Graham! If you're obsessed with the capital markets, and if you're at SFU, he's your best bet!

He is brilliant!!! Smartest. Really knows his stuff. Humorous.  Give all the pass MT FINAL questions. Provide formula pages on course webpage.  Even choice of philosophy or calculation question at FINAL!! Gives practical knowledge instead of only pure theories.  Lectures finish early and he runs sooo fast after every lecture.  Super recommend!!
Probably the most intelligent professor I've had at SFU. He knows A LOT. I like the course.

Geoffrey is undoubtedly smart and nice; however, the stuff that he teaches is not useful at all. He mostly teaches about the history and theories that are difficult but not practical. Exams are annoying as he only gives essay type of questions and difficult math questions. He doesn't really teach us about how to analyze securities. Don't recommend
Very very brilliant professor. Probably one of the smartest professor in Beedie.

Very Knowledgeable, but he is way too smart. He confuses the class and is very unclear about what he is saying. He tells you that you will learn this and that and in the end you learn nothing in the lectures. Read the book to understand what's happening and try to keep BUS 316 and calculus notes with you!
Lots of work, very useful material

Well, he's the only one teaching security analysis. He also wrote the textbook, which I found hard to read. First half of the class - prof's lectures on bonds, and lots of math. Second half of the class - students' presentations on stocks, and investment philosophies. Lots of work for this class so start your term paper early.
Terrific

He's a great teacher, I love stocks so I love hearing him rant about stocks and philosophies. Really ask him specific questions and how to do them. I would recommend to start early and ask how to do past midterm problems. However, I've had some friends who didn't like him because he can get off topic. Overall, I'd recommend him to you. Cheers

Not easy stuff, you have to pay attention to what he says in class. Write down everything he says and ask lots of questions. He gives you the exam questions in class and lets you ask questions about them, ASK ABOUT EACH QUESTION THAT ISN'T CLEAR, HE WILL EXPLAIN HOW TO ANSWER IT!  Individual project was fun and group project was easy.
Excellent professor!!!  Learned a lot from this industry pro.

This prof is a genius - the most intense brain during my four years at school. A math whiz who applies rocket science to study fixed income securities. Understands the limitations of math when dealing with equities - frequently disses modern portfolio theory.
Great business prof. Goes out of his way to help students. Rekindled my interest in finance.
smartest prof I've ever met
liked the group presentations best
best class
His textbooks are awesome!
very unclear what we need to do. The class is also messy, but this guy is fun...

Professor Carlos has been one of the most supportive professors I've had in SFU Beedie. He really does care for his students. He will help you with anything and I wish I had more business professors like him. Note - He does make you work for it, so the workload is demanding. Do not leave the final project last minute - but you will learn a lot.

This class with with Dr. Da Costa was demanding but good. I took two courses with him this semester so I can graduate this spring. He made the expectations and assignments clear. The group assignments took a good amount of time. He was easy to contact when needed. He cares about the students and notices the time put we put in.
Patrick manage his own firm. He is an excellent prof who provides students with practical experiences!

Patrick is one of the most polarizing professors at SFU. He is not like a normal professor, as he does not have an academic background. Having said that, I really enjoyed this class. He is very knowledgeable and eager to help.  I think it is imperative to have a class like this, where you gain experience that is closer to a professional setting.

Patrick is a very patient professor. Despite the questions are easy or difficult, his explanations are detailed and useful. He will answer your questions if you reach him in the class or at office hours. Try not to reach him by email cuz he is too busy to reply. He is a easy marker and the class is so interesting if you are into stock investment.
Amazing lecturer who makes you think outside the it. It's not all about theory but putting it into practice.
Good
He is bad. Avoid him. Learned nothing from him. his lecture and assignments are unclear.

WORST prof!!!!Avoid him!!!! His lectures takes full 4 hours and it's so boring. But he still expects you to follow him rather than falling asleep. If he finds you are not listening, he will ask you some weird questions. But actually no one can answer! He has no clear requirements on your team project. But he always think you should know it already!
Worst prof I've had in SFU. Never respond to students. No rules and marking scheme for assignment and project. Avoid him at all your cost. Do not recommend him for any class.

Avoid him!!!!! Worst prof I ever had. He promised he would teach us practical skills  but he never did. He just expected us to learn by ourselves. Never replied emails. No clear requirement s for group project but obviously has some weird requirements that he would never let you know.

He thought that everyone shouldn't care about grade, but we do care about the grade as a student. He will treat u more like employees, but u r not his employees.  All assignments' requirements are vague. U will never reach him through email. Always forgot to send the lecture slides before the class. Never told u there is an assignment.

Patrick teaches you the fundamentals and a way of thinking rather than have you memorize formulas. Gives you freedom on putting what you think is important in an assignment rather than tell you point by point. This is good but also causes confusion A LOT. He's pretty disorganized overall but passionate lecturer.

This is simply the best course of my undergrad degree. If you are a finance major, I'd strongly recommend taking this class with Patrick. You will learn a lot. Focus on getting good group members, and actually understand the project. If you understand the project you'll do fine in the exams.
Great professor.  Very practical material. Enjoyed the class
This is the greatest prof in SFU. His lecture is interesting and informative. The prof's class is practical and he will always tell you what happened in the real world.

I think for any higher level class, it is expected to know quite a bit of knowledge before even coming into class. Patrick is really nice and very helpful. The exam is not difficult and you can have good mark as long as you do all the work and also really being part of the project work.

Did not learn a lot as everything is already taught. WACC, FCF, DDM, RI are in 312,CAPM and bond is in 315, B/S pricing in 316. Slides are a bit too colourful and can be shortend. (the course takes more than 450 slides to discuss about less than 20 formula). Easy and good marker as BS-ing the report in 1 or 2 nights can still have decent grades :)
The material is actually not that hard, just read the textbook, but his notes are trash. He also tries to teach too much and ends up wasting your time.

WHAT THE HECK. This report is absolutely impossible to do.... what was he thinking??? this is an introductory security analysis course and hes making us valuate all aspects of the company with no real guidance whatsoever.
This is just too much work ...  BS a 25 pages equity analysis report in one night is inhumane.. regret ..
Awesome prof! You will learn a lot in this class but be prepared to do a lot of work. His notes could have less colours though.
Derek makes very complicated concepts very very simple.  I learned more in this class than I have in any other class I've taken, but it wasn't too much of a time burden.
